final_answer:
The humor in this image arises from the ironic situation depicted. On the left, a simplified silhouette of a person is confidently holding a "FASTPASS" ticket, suggesting they have a special advantage to bypass long queues. However, the right side of the image humorously contradicts this expectation by showing a long line of people waiting at the "FASTPASS ENTRANCE," implying that the supposed shortcut is no different from the regular line due to its own long queue.

The text "YES, BUT" emphasizes this contradiction, making the fastpass seem ineffective, as it does not provide the anticipated quick access. This satirical portrayal highlights the sometimes misplaced optimism in systems designed to expedite processes, which can instead lead to similar or unexpected delays.
ground_truth: The image is ironic, because fast pass entrance was meant for people to pass the gate fast but as more no. of people bought the pass due to which the queue has become longer and it becomes slow and time consuming
